problem: Max picks two different cards without replacement from a standard 52-card deck. What is the probability that the cards are of different suits?
solution: Once Max has chosen the first card, there are 51 cards remaining, of which 39 do not have the same suit as the first chosen card.  Therefore, the probability that the two cards have different suits is $\dfrac{39}{51} = \boxed{\frac{13}{17}}$.
model_solution:
There are 52 cards in the deck and Max picks 2 cards without replacement, so the sample space is 51 cards.
The probability that the first card is any suit is 52/52 = 1.
The first card can be any suit, but the second card must be a different suit.
The probability that the second card is a different suit is 39/51.
The probability that the first card is any suit and the second card is a different suit is (1)(39/51).
The probability that the first card is any suit and the second card is a different suit is (1)(39/51) = 39/51.
The probability that the cards are of different suits is 39/51 = 13/17.
The probability of the first card being any suit and the second card being a different suit is 39/51, so multiply this probability by 1 (since the first card can be any suit): (39/51)(1) = 39/51.
The probability that the first card is any suit and the second card is of a different suit is 39/51.
The probability that the first card is any suit and the second card is of a different suit is 13/17.
(39/51)(1) = 39/51.
Multiply this probability by 1 (since the first card can be any suit): (39/51)(1) = 39/51.
The probability that the first card is any suit and the second card is a different suit is 39/51.
